Posts.Title: Cannot believe what the neighbor said... Ang7 Shanagirl

Posts.Content: txstardust wrote: I had a BMX and DIEP recon on December 20.  My breast drains were removed about a week later.  I still had both hip drains until earlier this week, when one of them was removed even though it never went below that threshold of less than 30 ccs for 2 consecutive days.  The nurse mentioned that the remaining hip drain would increase slightly in output to compensate, but that it should go bback down, and I'd probably be able to have it removed by the end of this week.  Well, tomorrow is Friday, and not only is it nowhere close to low enough output to be removed, the output increased dramatically - from approximately 35-40 ccs per day, to 105 ccs today.   Is it normal to have a drain in for almost 4 weeks and the output to be that high?  I do have a lot of abdominal swelling, which I brought up to my surgeon at my appointment on Tuesday, but he didn't seem terribly concerned.  I know the best thing to do would be to call the office tomorrow, but I hate to be a pest - I've already called the nurse twice in the last week over other issues which turned out to be nothing.  I guess I just want to know whether it's within normal limits, and therefore not worth taking the time to bother them.   Has anyone else experienced this?  Dx 8/10/2009, IDC, Right, 2cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 2/21 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: still have drain 3.5 weeks after DIEP - is this normal? txstardust txstardust

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2012 10:06PM txstardust wrote: One additional questions - would I be able to go ack to work next week if I still have the drain?  What would be the pros and cons? Thanks :)
Posts.Title: still have drain 3.5 weeks after DIEP - is this normal? txstardust txstardust

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2012 08:32AM txstardust wrote: Thanks for the replies, ladies.  I called my PS office, and the nurse didn't seem too concerned about the drain volume.  She said it's better to leave it in, because of the risk of seroma, as you mentioned, gardengumby.  I apologized for being a worrywart, and she was so sweet and told me to call any time if I have a question.  It's just difficult to know what is normal and what needs to get checked out.  If only the output would go down, so I can get the darn thing out!!  Every time it seems like it's decreasing for a day or two, it goes right back up again.  Yesterday, back up to 109 cc's.  It's so annoying and frustrating!  It would be nice if I could just stay off my feet for another week to see if that helps, but I have to get back to work tomorrow - I've already exhausted my sick leave, and am now on unpaid leave.  I can make it a few days without pay, but no longer.  I'm a single mom with two teenagers, and that's not cheap. Good luck with your recovery, evebarry, and take it easy!
Posts.Title: still have drain 3.5 weeks after DIEP - is this normal? txstardust txstardust

Posts.Content: May 26, 2011 10:36AM txstardust wrote: Oh Nana, I am so so sorry that you're having to go through this pain.  I went through a divorce myself, immediately after I finished rads.  While my husband was not cheating on me with another woman, he was cheating on me with alcohol - that was his "other woman".  While going through chemo, I ended up in the hospital with a life-threatening infection.  I was in the hospital for 5 days.  He came to visit me ONE TIME.  The rest of the time, he was in the bar drinking. It is so painful to realize that the one who is supposed to be our greatest supporter and ally has chosen not to do so.  I finally came to realize after much struggle that my marriage was already over; I just needed to file the paperwork.   I am NOT saying that you should get a divorce.  But know that if things don't work out, that you have options, and that you should do what is best for YOU.
Posts.Title: Cheating Husband teamnana car2tenn

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2010 09:24AM txstardust wrote: Lynn, I know it's very scary to feel a lump in your breast!  Since I've already been through a breast cancer diagnosis, I felt that fear a little over a month ago when I found a new lump in my breast.  It turned out to be something called "fat necrosis".  Here is some information about fat necrosis.  from http://www.medterms.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=24986. Breast trauma: Physical damage to a breast. If a breast is injured by trauma, tiny blood vessels may rupture to cause localized bleeding (a hematoma). The hematoma can be felt as a lump. Trauma to the breast can also damage the fat cells in the breast tissue, a condition called fat necrosis. Fat necrosis can form a lump in the breast. This type of lump is not cancer. That being said, it can be difficult to tell the difference between necrosis and breast cancer by feel.  At the very least, you should get a mammogram and/or ultrasound and have a doctor evaluate you.
Posts.Title: Not sure if this is serious or not? Lynn97 Sherryc

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2010 11:46AM txstardust wrote: Tiffany, I was just saying the same thing yesterday.  My DH keeps exclaiming how I just have "one more" (my last chemo tx is next week), it's "almost over", etc. etc.  I understand that one phase of my tx is over, and I know he's happy about it since it has been a nightmare for me, but it's not over and never will be.  He asked me if they do a scan when chemo is over to know if it worked.  I told him there is no scan that can tell them if I have no cancer cells in my body and that I'll never know.  I think he was humbled.  People just don't get it.   I'm sorry you're feeling this way, but I wanted you to know that you're not the only one struggling with this! Peace to you, Shelby
